Nouns

Nouns represent all that are tangible. If a word signifies a person, animal, place, thing, or idea, then it is a noun. In Filipino, nouns are called pangngalan. This should not be confused with the Filipino term pangalan which means "name" and not "noun" in English.

Proper and Common Nouns

There are two types of nouns: proper nouns and common nouns. Proper nouns are nouns that refer to a specific person, animal, place, thing, or idea. Common nouns are less unique and refer to a general material entity. Proper nouns are capitalized while common nouns are not.

Example: Marikit - proper noun, tao [human] - common noun

Uses of Nouns

Nouns have a variety of uses in sentences. In Filipino, there are three uses for nouns in a sentence:

  • Palagyo - Nominative Case
  • Palayon - Objective Case
  • Paari - Possessive Case

I. Pangngalang Palagyo - Nominative Noun

Nominative nouns are nouns that are used as the subject or further describes the subject of a sentence. The subject performs the action in the sentence.

a. Simuno - Subject

The subject is the noun that performs the action in the sentence.

Example: Si Marikit [Marikit] ay [is] maganda [beautiful].

b. Pantawag - Caller

Sometimes nouns are used to call or address someone. Usually the name of the person being spoke to is the first word spoken, followed by a comma.

Example: Marikit [Marikit], ikaw [you] ay [are] maganda [beautiful].

c. Kaganapang Pansimuno - Subject Complement

Subject complements are nouns that further describe the subject of the sentence.

Example: Si Marikit [Marikit], isang doktor [a doctor], ay [is] maganda [beautiful].

II. Pangngalang Palayon - Objective Noun

Objective nouns are nouns that are used as the object of the sentence. The object is the recipient of the action in the sentence.

a. Layon ng Pandiwa - Object of Verb

The object of the verb is the noun that receives the action of the verb.

Example: Si Marikit [Marikit] ay kumain ng [ate] isang mansanas [an apple].

b. Layon ng Pang-ukol - Object of Preposition

The object of the preposition is the noun that receives the action of the preposition.

Example: Si Marikit [Marikit] ay nasa [is in] isang kotse [a car].

III. Pangngalang Paari - Possessive Noun

Possessive nouns are nouns that are used to show ownership of something. In English, possessive nouns are usually shown by adding an apostrophe and an "s" to the end of the noun. In Filipino, possessive nouns are shown by adding the word ng or ni after the noun.

Examples: Ang [The] kotse ni Marikit [car of Marikit] ay [is] malaki [big].
Ang [The] kotse ng doktor [doctor's car] ay [is] maliit [small].

Activity 1: Active Recall for Noun Translations

For this activity, we shall look at commonly-used nouns and their Filipino translation. Here we can see a picture of a noun, the English word, and the Filipino translation. The order is initially nonrandomized. You can choose to hide the Filipino translation and turn on randomization to test yourself.

Image

English Word

Filipino Translation

Pig

Baboy

Activity 2: Translate It On Your Own (Nouns)

For this activity, we will be translating English nouns to Filipino. There is an English word shown, and you have to type in the Filipino translation. Don't worry, the input box is case-insensitive. You can also switch to Filipino-to-English and back!

Filipino Translation
